natural problem: Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color?
natural solution: We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 1 - ((26/52) * (25/51) * (24/50))"
shows  "prob = 13 / 17"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: real
assumes h0 : "prob = 1 - ((26/52) * (25/51) * (24/50))"
shows  "prob = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: In a deck of cards, what is the probability of drawing at least one face card (jack, queen, or king) in the first three draws without replacement? The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..3}. (26 - i + 1)) / (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..3}. (52 - i + 1))"
shows  "1 - prob = 13 / 17"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..3}. (26 - i + 1)) / (\<Prod>i\<in>{1..3}. (52 - i + 1))"
shows  "1 - prob = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: In a deck of 52 playing cards, what is the probability that the first three cards drawn are not the same suit? Express your answer as a fraction. The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda> c. card c) {c | c \<in> {1..52} \<and> (\<forall> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<longrightarrow> (c1 \<in> c \<and> c2 \<in> c \<and> c3 \<in> c) \<and> (\<exists> col. \<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card \<noteq> col))}"
and h1 : "p = (\<lambda> c. card c) {c | c \<in> {1..52} \<and> (\<forall> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<longrightarrow> (c1 \<in> c \<and> c2 \<in> c \<and> c3 \<in> c) \<and> (\<exists> col1 col2. (\<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card = col1 \<or> card_color card = col2) \<and> col1 \<noteq> col2))}"
and h2 : "p = 13 / 17"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> c. \<not> (\<exists> col. \<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card = col)) = 13 / 17"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda> c. card c) {c | c \<in> {1..52} \<and> (\<forall> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<longrightarrow> (c1 \<in> c \<and> c2 \<in> c \<and> c3 \<in> c) \<and> (\<exists> col. \<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card \<noteq> col))}"
and h1 : "p = (\<lambda> c. card c) {c | c \<in> {1..52} \<and> (\<forall> c1 c2 c3. c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> c2 \<noteq> c3 \<and> c1 \<noteq> c3 \<longrightarrow> (c1 \<in> c \<and> c2 \<in> c \<and> c3 \<in> c) \<and> (\<exists> col1 col2. (\<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card = col1 \<or> card_color card = col2) \<and> col1 \<noteq> col2))}"
and h2 : "p = 13 / 17"
shows  "probability (\<lambda> c. \<not> (\<exists> col. \<forall> card \<in> c. card_color card = col)) = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: In a deck of 52 cards, what is the probability of drawing three cards such that at least two different colors are represented among the drawn cards? The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes cards_total cards_same_color cards_diff_color :: real
assumes h0 : "cards_total = 52"
and h1 : "cards_same_color = 26"
and h2 : "cards_diff_color = cards_total - cards_same_color"
and h3 : "prob_not_same_color = 1 - ((cards_same_color * (cards_same_color - 1) * (cards_same_color - 2)) / (cards_total * (cards_total - 1) * (cards_total - 2)))"
shows  "prob_not_same_color = 13 / 17"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes cards_total cards_same_color cards_diff_color :: real
assumes h0 : "cards_total = 52"
and h1 : "cards_same_color = 26"
and h2 : "cards_diff_color = cards_total - cards_same_color"
and h3 : "prob_not_same_color = 1 - ((cards_same_color * (cards_same_color - 1) * (cards_same_color - 2)) / (cards_total * (cards_total - 1) * (cards_total - 2)))"
shows  "prob_not_same_color = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: In a deck of 52 playing cards, there are 26 cards of the same color. What is the probability that when you draw 3 cards, they are not all of the same color? Express your answer as a common fraction. The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_4.informal problem: What is the probability of drawing at least one face card (Jack, Queen, or King) from a standard deck of 52 playing cards in three draws without replacement? The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (1 - (26/52) * (25/51) * (24/50))"
shows  "P = 13 / 17"

(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}

 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]

a_5.informal problem: Calculate the probability $P$ of not drawing three consecutive cards of the same suit from a standard deck of 52 cards. The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda> A B. card A / card B)"
and h1 : "card (all_cards :: 'a set) = 52"
and h2 : "card (red_cards :: 'a set) = 26"
and h3 : "card (black_cards :: 'a set) = 26"
and h4 : "card (chosen_cards :: 'a set) = 3"
and h5 : "not_all_same_color (chosen_cards :: 'a set)"
shows  "prob (chosen_cards) (all_cards) = 13 / 17"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes prob :: "real"
assumes h0 : "prob = (\<lambda> A B. card A / card B)"
and h1 : "card (all_cards :: 'a set) = 52"
and h2 : "card (red_cards :: 'a set) = 26"
and h3 : "card (black_cards :: 'a set) = 26"
and h4 : "card (chosen_cards :: 'a set) = 3"
and h5 : "not_all_same_color (chosen_cards :: 'a set)"
shows  "prob (chosen_cards) (all_cards) = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: A deck of 52 cards contains 26 red cards and 26 black cards. If three cards are chosen such that not all of them are the same color, what is the probability of this event? The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P_not_same_color :: real
assumes h0 : "P_not_same_color = (1 - (26 choose 3)/(52 choose 3))"
shows  "P_not_same_color = 13 / 17"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P_not_same_color :: real
assumes h0 : "P_not_same_color = (1 - (26 choose 3)/(52 choose 3))"
shows  "P_not_same_color = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: A deck of 52 playing cards contains 26 red cards and 26 black cards. If three cards are drawn at random, without replacement, what is the probability that all three cards are not the same color? The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> (x :: real). x * (x - 1) * (x - 2) / (52 * 51 * 50))"
and h1 : "P 26 = probability that all three cards are the same color"
shows  "1 - P 26 = 13 / 17"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<lambda> (x :: real). x * (x - 1) * (x - 2) / (52 * 51 * 50))"
and h1 : "P 26 = probability that all three cards are the same color"
shows  "1 - P 26 = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: In a deck of 52 cards with 26 red cards and 26 black cards, three cards are drawn without replacement. Let $P(x)$ be the probability that all three cards are the same color, where $x$ is the number of red cards in the deck. Find the probability that not all three cards are the same color. The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. (binomial 26 i) * (binomial 26 (3 - i)) / binomial 52 3)"
shows  "P = 13 / 17"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Three cards are chosen at random from a standard 52-card deck.  What is the probability that they are not all the same color? The final Answer is \frac{13}{17}
 ### Proof
 We can find the probability they are all same color, then subtract that from 1. There are 26 cards of each color, so 3 of them can be selected in $\binom{26}{3}$ ways, and of course there are 2 colors.
 So the answer is \[1-2\frac{\binom{26}{3}}{\binom{52}{3}}=\boxed{\frac{13}{17}}.\]
 *)

theorem
fixes P :: "real"
assumes h0 : "P = (\<Sum>i\<in>{0..3}. (binomial 26 i) * (binomial 26 (3 - i)) / binomial 52 3)"
shows  "P = 13 / 17"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the probability $P$ of drawing exactly 3 cards from a standard 52-card deck such that the number of red cards and black cards drawn follows the binomial coefficient formula: $P = \sum_{i=0}^{3} \frac{\binom{26}{i} \cdot \binom{26}{3-i}}{\binom{52}{3}}$. The final answer is $\frac{13}{17}$.
